## 1. Why coal‑related air‑pollution deaths are a “life‑cycle” issue  

When we talk about “deaths per TWh of electricity” we are not only counting the people who die while a miner is underground or a turbine blows up.  
The *dominant* share of the mortality burden for coal comes from **ambient (out‑door) and indoor air pollution** that is emitted while the coal is *burned* to make electricity.  

| Pollutant | Typical source in a coal‑fired power plant | Main health end‑points |
|----------|--------------------------------------------|------------------------|
| **Particulate matter (PM₂.₅)** | Combustion of carbon → fine soot; also secondary formation from SO₂, NOₓ, ammonia | Cardiovascular disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), lung cancer, premature death |
| **Sulphur dioxide (SO₂)** | Oxidation of sulphur in coal | Asthma attacks, bronchitis, contributes to secondary PM₂.₅ |
| **Nitrogen oxides (NOₓ)** | High‑temperature combustion | Respiratory irritation, contributes to ozone and secondary PM₂.₅ |
| **Mercury (Hg)** | Volatilisation of trace Hg in coal | Neurological damage (especially in fetuses/children), cardiovascular effects |
| **Carbon monoxide (CO)** | Incomplete combustion | Acute poisoning at high concentrations (rare for modern stacks) |
| **Poly‑cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs)** | Incomplete combustion | Lung cancer, mutagenic effects |

The **dose‑response relationship** that links the ambient concentration of these pollutants to mortality has been quantified in large epidemiological studies (e.g., the *Global Burden of Disease* (GBD) project, the *Health Effects Institute* (HEI) “Epidemiologic Review”, and the *U.S. EPA* Integrated Risk Information System). Those studies give us a **concentration‑response coefficient (β)** that tells us how many extra deaths occur per 1 µg m⁻³ increase in annual average PM₂.₅ (or per unit increase in SO₂/NOₓ, etc.).

The most widely used single‑metric is **PM₂.₅** because it captures the bulk of the mortality impact of all the other pollutants (they either form fine particles in the atmosphere or act as precursors).  

> **Key epidemiologic result (2021 Global Burden of Disease, 2020 data):**  
> An increase of **10 µg m⁻³** in long‑term average PM₂.₅ exposure is associated with a **~ 7 %** increase in all‑cause mortality (relative risk = 1.07, 95 % CI ≈ 1.05–1.09).  

All subsequent calculations start from that coefficient.

---

## 2. Step‑by‑step calculation of mortality from a coal plant  

Below is a *simplified* but realistic workflow that most peer‑reviewed life‑cycle assessments (LCAs) follow. Numbers are illustrative; the same method can be applied to any plant or region.

### 2.1 Gather plant‑specific emission data  

| Parameter | Typical value for a 500 MW modern subcritical coal plant (U.S./Europe) |
|-----------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Coal throughput | ~ 3 Mt yr⁻¹ (≈ 6 kg s⁻¹) |
| PM₂.₅ (primary) | 0.02 kg MWh⁻¹ (≈ 10 g MWh⁻¹) |
| SO₂ | 2 kg MWh⁻¹ |
| NOₓ | 1.5 kg MWh⁻¹ |
| Hg | 0.02 g MWh⁻¹ |

These are **stack‑exit** emissions after any on‑site controls (e.g., electrostatic precipitators, flue‑gas desulphurisation).

## 1. What “lives saved” really means  

When we talk about **“lives saved per year”** after a fuel‑switch we are usually referring to the *difference in the estimated number of premature deaths* that would occur **over the whole life‑cycle** of the electricity that is produced.  

The life‑cycle death‑rates most often quoted in the peer‑reviewed literature are  

| Fuel | Mean deaths per TWh (electricity) | Range in the literature* |
|------|-----------------------------------|--------------------------|
| Coal | **≈ 25 deaths / TWh** (≈ 0.025 deaths / MWh) | 10 – 50 deaths / TWh |
| Nuclear | **≈ 0.05 deaths / TWh** (≈ 0.00005 deaths / MWh) | 0.02 – 0.12 deaths / TWh |

\*The spread reflects different health‑impact models (e.g., GBD vs. EPA’s BenMAP), different assumptions about how many people are exposed, and whether long‑term cancer risk from Chernobyl/Fukushima is fully counted.

**If a country moves X TWh of electricity from coal to nuclear, the expected number of lives saved in a year is roughly**

\[
\text{Lives saved} \;\approx\; X\;(\text{deaths / TWh}_\text{coal} - \text{deaths / TWh}_\text{nuclear})
\]

Using the “mid‑point” values 25 – 0.05 ≈ 24.95 deaths / TWh, the rule‑of‑thumb becomes:

> **≈ 25 lives saved for every 1 TWh of electricity shifted from coal to nuclear.**  

Below we apply that rule to a few real‑world cases, then discuss why the impact can be *much larger* (or smaller) in certain regions.

---

## 2. Concrete country‑level examples  

| Country / Region | Current coal electricity (2023) | Plausible coal‑to‑nuclear shift (TWh yr⁻¹) | Estimated lives saved / yr* |
|------------------|--------------------------------|--------------------------------------------|-----------------------------|
| **United States** (total 2023 coal generation ≈ 600 TWh) | 600 TWh | 30 TWh (≈ 5 % of current coal) – roughly the size of the **Palo Verde** nuclear plant (≈ 4 TWh) plus a small new unit | **≈ 750 deaths/yr** |
| **Germany** (coal ≈ 130 TWh in 2022) | 130 TWh | 10 TWh (≈ 8 % of coal, the amount that could be covered by the **EPR** at **GKN** if it were built) | **≈ 250 deaths/yr** |
| **Poland** (coal ≈ 150 TWh, most of the grid) | 150 TWh | 20 TWh (≈ 13 % – a realistic first‑phase nuclear programme) | **≈ 500 deaths/yr** |
| **India** (coal ≈ 1 200 TWh, many plants have minimal emission controls) | 1 200 TWh | 30 TWh (≈ 2.5 % – roughly the output of a 3 GW nuclear plant) | **≈ 750 deaths/yr** |
| **China** (coal ≈ 3 400 TWh, but many plants already have advanced SO₂/NOₓ controls) | 3 400 TWh | 50 TWh (≈ 1.5 % – comparable to the combined output of the **Guangdong** and **Fukang** nuclear sites)
